column13: We established APAÃ¢ÂÂs Pathfinder Program in FY21 to understand what is required to support clean molecules in existing and new infrastructure. Pathfinder continues investigating other hydrogen and carbon capture and storage project opportunities where APA can apply market-leading energy infrastructure expertise and experience to large-scale projects.
column14: In FY23, we completed a technical feasibility study under the Program for converting the Parmelia Pipeline (PGP) to 100% hydrogen.

column13: In May 2023, our landmark Parmelia Gas Pipeline (PGP) conversion project in Western Australia confirmed, via pressurised hydrogen laboratory testing, the technical feasibility of converting a 43-kilometre section of the PGP to carry 100% hydrogen.
column14: The testing results indicate it is technically feasible, safe and efficient to run the 43-kilometre section of the pipeline at current operating pressure using hydrogen.
column20: Parmelia Gas Pipeline, Western Australia, Hydrogen Laboratory Testing

column8: Net Zero Emissions Data and Reporting Project
column13: In FY24, APA will start our Net Zero Emissions Data and Reporting Project. This project will deliver a single source of truth emissions data and reporting platform with automated data flows for Scope 1, 2, and 3 and end-user emissions.
column20: Net Zero Emissions, Data, Reporting Project

column13: Renewable electricity is one of the opportunities in the field of energy sources. It will be implemented through a renewable electricity procurement strategy, achieving 100 renewable electricity targets for FY23 in the short to long term by group-wide asset class.
column20: Renewable Electricity, Energy Sources, Procurement Strategy

column13: In FY23, APA commissioned our first-ever hybrid energy microgrid, supplying the remote Gruyere Gold Mine in Western Australia. The project included an expansion of our existing gas-fired generation and installing a 13 MW solar farm backed up by a 4.4 MW/4.4 MWh battery energy storage system.\t
column14: As a result, we have increased our total generation and storage capacity at Gruyere from 47 MW to 64 MW. We are expected to deliver an overall reduction in emissions intensity for our customers. We expect the overall carbon intensity to reduce by 10%.
column20: Hybrid Energy Microgrid, Gruyere Gold Mine, Fired-Gas Generation

column13: Core business activities such as procurement of goods and services and business travel make up about 40%1 % of our Scope 3 emissions. As part of our approach to tackling these core operational emissions, we fully committed to offset all business travel.
column14: As a result, we delivered a net emissions reduction of 5,646 t CO2-e by surrendering an equivalent volume of ACCUs.
column20: Procurement, Business Travel, Operational Emissions

column13: APA has supported broader supply chain decarbonisation through participation in the Climate Leaders Coalition. This participation supported the development of the Scope 3 Roadmap and the GasCo proof of concept.

column7: APA calculates the intensity of power generation emissions for all power generation facilities under APAÃ¢ÂÂs operational control. Power generation emissions intensity is calculated by dividing the gross Scope 1 and Scope 2 emissions (t CO2-e) by the total electricity (MWh) produced. Reported in t CO2-e/MWh. \t

column7: In FY23, APA resulted in a reduction of 6.7% (net) and 3.7% (gross) greenhouse gas emissions reduction from gas infrastructure from the target of 30% reduction (net) by 2030.
column13: APA delivered a 3.7% gross reduction in APA's greenhouse gas emissions primarily through procuring 100% renewable electricity in FY23. It has resulted in zero Scope 2 emissions for our gas infrastructure assets.

column8: Re-baselining APA Orbost Divestment and Methodology Changes
column13: In FY23, we re-baselined APAÃ¢ÂÂs FY21 (base year) inventory and FY22 emissions values by the Greenhouse Gas Protocol and APAÃ¢ÂÂs re-baselining principles. The main changes were principally due to:\nÃ¢ÂÂ¢ divesting the Orbost Gas Processing Plant (OGPP) with operational control ceasing in May 2023\nÃ¢ÂÂ¢ a change in the National Greenhouse Energy Reporting (NGER) (measurement) Determination relating to fugitive emissions from gas storage and our distribution networks.
column14: It resulted in proportionate adjustments to the target emissions trajectory needed to achieve our commitment of a 30% emissions reduction by 2030 and a 3.3% annual emissions reduction (relative to the revised FY21 baseline).\t

column13: Gas pipelines in Australia are regulated under the National Gas Law (NGL) and National Gas Rules (NGR) by the Australian Energy Regulator (AER) or the Economic Regulation Authority of Western Australia (ERA). On 2 March 2023, amendments to the NGL and NGR were proclaimed and enacted across all States except Western Australia.
